Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An Affordable Metal Additive Manufacturing Machine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I Project aims to tackle the two greatest barriers to technology adoption associated with metal additive manufacturing (AM) - cost and quantities. Current metal AM platforms use expensive core components and consumable materials in high-priced machines that produce 99.9% dense parts. The proposed project introduces a lower performance, affordable stainless steel additive manufacturing technology that will be capable of satisfying the vast majority of customer needs for industrial grade stainless steel parts. The vast majority of the market simply cannot afford to take advantage of AM benefits due to the high costs associated with current technologies. This proposal re-examines the material performance, machine cost and reliability requirements necessary for a novel metal AM system. The goal of the proposal is to allow an estimated 50,000+ American manufacturers to capitalize on the benefits of AM and compete to win in an ultra-competitive, highly globalized manufacturing industry. Furthermore, the proposed invention of a low-cost machine allows for unprecedented scalability in metal AM, allowing smaller manufacturers to compete with the resources of large conglomerates. This research has broad implications in many industries and is considered to be fundamentally enabling for the growth and prosperity of American manufacturing.


The proposed project re-examines the need for high technology, high cost core components in currently available commercial metallic AM machines. Through an innovative deconstruction of the inkjet print head-based, binder jetting process, a method for producing metal end-use parts has been created. The proposed process is based on a novel combination of two low cost and established technologies. The creation of a robust prototype with this novel method is a highly challenging, multi-faceted project involving key advances in materials science through the development of a novel binder system compatible with the new process as well as a fundamental evaluation and improvement of material properties of the as-built parts. In addition, re-designed sintering cycles and development of software prediction algorithms to anticipate shrinkage characteristics will be core challenges to overcome in order to achieve the tight tolerances manufacturing partners require. As such, these challenges will require tight cross-disciplinary collaboration for a meaningful outcome. The ultimate goal of the proposed research is to fabricate powder metallurgy parts of adequate structural integrity to satisfy industrial end-use requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The ultimate goal of 3DEO’s NSF SBIR Phase I proposal was to develop an entirely new, revolutionary metal additive manufacturing (AM) process that significantly reduces the cost of printing parts. The proposed system was successfully designed to build low-cost, reliable stainless-steel alloy parts from standard MIM powders. As a brief overview, the six fundamental steps of the Intelligent Layering® process are described in Figure 1.

Intellectual Merit

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will result in a commercialized metal AM manufacturing process capable of producing near full density three-dimensional parts at a fraction of the cost of currently available metal AM technologies. This cost advantage is only made possible through the combination of deep multi-disciplinary expertise, continued innovation in the core technology, a novel combination of existing technologies, and the use of commodity feedstock materials. The ultimate goal of this effort is to create a metal AM manufacturing technology that will not only break down the cost barriers associated with the current state of metal AM, but also compete with existing traditional metal component manufacturing techniques in low/medium-volume production. The proposed research requires a cross-functional development effort in software, materials and electro-mechanical, resulting in a highly robust and differentiated additive manufacturing technology.

Broader Impacts

3DEO is on a mission to do for manufacturing what the personal computer did for society. The personal computer unleashed unparalleled creativity and innovation in society. Before the PC, previously expensive and inaccessible computing power was available only to those willing and able to pay exorbitant prices. Thanks to Moore’s Law and unstoppable entrepreneurial energy, personal computers opened new frontiers and allowed everyone in society to leverage the advantages gained by raw computing power.

Similarly, there is currently no low-cost, high-volume metal AM technology in the market capable of reliably creating production parts that meet existing industry quality standards. Driving down both costs and required expertise creates unprecedented accessibility to cutting edge manufacturing capabilities. Today, new up-and-coming manufacturers can be at a significant disadvantage compared to established manufacturers. 3DEO levels the playing field, allowing all manufacturers to compete. This technology will unleash creativity in society as a new generation of designers will be able to develop innovative applications.

In addition, 3D printing also benefits society in other important ways. It holds tremendous potential to reduce the environmental impact of manufacturing. Distributed manufacturing is truly possible with 3DEO’s low-cost infrastructure, which reduces the carbon footprint of moving materials and parts around the globe. 3DEO is also able to recycle its unused metal powder resulting in negligible waste in the process, compared to CNC machining that can waste as much as 95% of the raw material.

Award Outcomes

The National Science Foundation funding enabled 3DEO to overcome all Phase I proposed technical objectives in the six-month duration of this project.

As a direct result of NSF Phase I funding, 3DEO was able to rapidly invent, iterate on, and develop a novel metal AM process that currently produces 99% dense, 17-4PH stainless steel parts that are held to a widely accepted industry benchmark, MPIF Standard 35. The measured surface roughness (Ra) on one side of the part was 150 µin which is significantly lower than parts produced via other AM processes (~300-600 µin). 

Figure 2 is an illustration of the first class of parts built with the 3DEO prototype Intelligent Layering® system. The true technical breakthrough in development occurred after many dozen spray technologies had failed. The technical team invented an entirely new binder deposition method that could reliably and repeatably create very thin layers of bound powder. In addition, 3DEO developed compatible binder/powder systems for part printing. The materials development effort enabled the team to utilize off-the-shelf metal injection molding (MIM) powders, the finest powders in the AM industry to date. Finally, through exhaustive internal development, 3DEO designed and implemented custom software so that we could begin part printing of several geometries for process testing. This project culminated in the qualification of our 3D printed parts to MPIF Standard 35.

The result of this NSF Phase I proposal has been to prove the Intellectual Merit of the proposed technology in order to demonstrate feasibility and proceed with a Phase II application. 3DEO’s technology can finally unlock the full potential of metal additive manufacturing for high volume applications of 10,000 pieces or more. While working toward the completion of Phase I objectives, the technical team identified several revolutionary advantages of the Intelligent Layering® technology. As part of the Phase II effort, 3DEO will fully investigate these novel capabilities to commercialize a truly breakthrough, and accessible AM technology.
